ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Randy, Please see below. ... Thanks. I m glad you found it interesting. ... But we already know the result of that experiment. Ken has shown that

From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=dY77f8U8SNrWKHPUgm-w10SC8Q8V3ZY91pbNFKRXBHg7sVJZWp_v
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune


--Apple-Mail=_711D1AE8-8CBF-4511-AE19-76C092D029B2
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Randy,

Please see below. 

> Hey Jeff,
> 
> This is cool work and I =
think it's a good step toward addressing a fundamentally interesting questi=
on: How can we seed an evolving 3D object generator with a predetermined ob=
ject? It's also a great example of what I was talking about in my previous =
comment in response to Ken. First, I'll answer your question.
> 
> 

Thanks=
. I'm glad you found it interesting. 

> > I won't take any criticism of ou=
r paper personally. I just think that sometimes arguments are more informat=
ive when there is a specific example to be discussed, instead of remaining =
entirely abstract. I also think this paper is a nice example of a technique=
 that can't be quantified in an informative way, yet remains an interesting=
 contribution. If you were our reviewer, would you insist upon a quantitati=
ve comparison for this paper? How would you recommend such a test be made? =
Do you agree that we should encourage reviewers to reject such papers, or t=
hat we should work to encourage reviewers to consider such papers?
> 
> I a=
gree that it's hard to quantify the results in this paper because the resul=
t is "yup, it worked in my system." At this point, the best you could've do=
ne was (as you mentioned) compared it to how closely targeted evolution get=
s to the desired target. Since you have a measure of how "close" the phenot=
ype is to the target phenotype (distanceFromSurface), you can quantify the =
distance from the desired target that each method achieves. Of course, each=
 method would need to be run in replicate at least 30 times to get a reason=
able mean and 95% confidence interval.
> 
> 

But we already know the resul=
t of that experiment. Ken has shown that target-based evolution doesn't wor=
k, so the error for target-based evolution will be non-zero (and likely lar=
ge). But (as we mention in the paper) the error in our method can be tuned =
toward zero by increasing the resolution of the workspace, so the error for=
 the Seeded-CPPN technique effectively is zero. Thus, we know ahead of time=
 that our method won't produce error. The only uncertainty is how bad targe=
t based evolution would be, but that is not the focus of this paper, so the=
 experiment would be off-topic. In other words, we introduce a technique th=
at eliminates the issue of error, since it skips right to the correct shape=
=85to compare it against an obviously bad technique that we know produces e=
rror would only be to satisfy reviewers that insist on quantification; it d=
oes not address a broader hypothesis, no?

> Some more comments about the p=
aper:
> 
> Here's what I got from the paper: You wanted to create a method =
to seed a 3D object generator with a predetermined 3D object. You devised a=
 method to enable this feature based on CPPNs. You showed that it works pre=
tty well and matches the desired object on EndlessForms.
> 
> Notice how ea=
ch sentence narrows the relevant audience down more and more. The question =
went from "How do I seed a 3D object generator with a predetermined object?=
" to "How do I seed a 3D object generator based on CPPNs with a predetermin=
ed object?" to "How do I seed my 3D object generator based on CPPNs, Endles=
sForms, with a predetermined object?"
> 
The last statement is too narrow. =
While we used some examples from EndlessForms, we also used many example ob=
jects from Thingiverse that were not produced on EndlessForms and show that=
 the Seeded-CPPN technique works for any object. I'd argue that we actually=
 answered the first, broadest question as well: one answer to how to seed a=
 3D object generator with a predetermined object is to use the Seeded-CPPN =
technique. 

> 
> Let's say I had my own 3D object generating website, Unli=
mitedForms, but it was based on regular ANNs. What could I take from this p=
aper?
> 
You would know that you could seed objects if you switch to CPPNs =
and use the Seeded-CPPN technique. That sounds cheeky (sorry, I'm in the UK=
 at the moment), but I think it is the honest answer to your question. I do=
n't think that's a narrow answer, either: in your current system what you w=
ant has not been invented, and may not be possible, but this paper shows an=
 alternative technique that can accomplish the goal. 

> Or what if I was o=
nly interested in 2D pictures, but still wanted to seed them similarly? Or =
what if I have no interest in evolving 2D/3D objects at all, but want to kn=
ow clever methods for seeding a GA with a predetermined phenotype? These ar=
e all important points to consider when presenting a new method, especially=
 because everyone has their own pet method that they like to use.
> 
> If y=
ou did the work discussed in Section 4B for this paper, you would have a mu=
ch easier time quantifying the results. You also would've gotten at a much =
more broadly interesting question about evolvability while simultaneously p=
resenting your new technique.
> 
> 
Agreed. Any paper would be stronger if =
it also did its Future Work section. In fact, a lot of the reviewers were u=
pset that so much time in the paper was spent discussing the future work th=
at this technique enables. But I believe that's often precisely what makes =
new techniques interesting: the possibilities they enable. There is always =
a tension between doing the future work, or just mentioning that it can be =
done. For a conference paper, I think it is fine to publish a smaller packa=
ge of work and point to future possible work. But I'd like to point out tha=
t whether there is enough work in this paper is orthogonal to the quantitat=
ive vs. qualitative discussion. Quite a bit of the future evolvability work=
 would also be qualitative. One could say "you should have done the quantit=
ative portions of the future work, because then you'd at least have somethi=
ng quantitive." That's clearly the prudent strategy given that some reviewe=
rs won't accept a paper unless it has a few quantitative comparisons, but t=
his discussion is about whether that demand for some quantitative compariso=
n should be the prevailing attitude. There's plenty of work in this area th=
at won't be quantifiable=85.and saying that it has to be packaged with some=
thing quantitative shows that we have a bizarre "checkbox rule" for papers:=
 you can publish something qualitative and interesting, but only if you als=
o pair it with some quantifiable metric so you check the quantitative box. =
If the qualitative work is inadmissible as science, as the GECCO reviewer f=
or this paper claimed, then it shouldn't be publishable even as a sub-secti=
on of a paper. And if it is admissible, then it should be able to be publis=
hable on its own (if there is enough of such qualitative work to be a publi=
shable unit).  

> Also, given that this is a methods paper, I'm surprised =
the methods section is so short. The new technique that you introduced in t=
his paper (Section 2C) only received about 2/3 page of text, and no figures=
 dedicated to it. From my first two reads through that section, I still don=
't completely understand how the method works. I would say that that would =
be the critical section of the paper for readers to understand if they were=
 to use your technique, worthy of at least one figure and more detailed exp=
lanation.
> 
> 
I'm sorry we didn't make it clear to you. Of course, that i=
ssue is also orthogonal to the quantitative vs. qualitative conversation, b=
ut it is something I would like to address. Can you tell me what questions =
you have? I'd be happy to try to answer them in this thread. If anyone read=
ing this also has questions about the technique, please let me know. 

Than=
ks for the fascinating conversation. I am enjoying it! I appreciate you voi=
cing your constructive criticisms of the paper. I also appreciate your posi=
tive comments about it. 


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Co=
mputer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com



> =
Cheers,
> Randy
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff" <jclune@...> wrote=
:
> >
> > Hello all,
> > 
> > Our recent conversation in this "Quantitative=
 vs. Qualitative Results" thread was started in part because a paper I am o=
n was rejected from GECCO for not having any quantitative results. That pap=
er was recently accepted at CEC. I'd be interested to hear your thoughts on=
 this paper in light of our conversation now that you can see the specific =
paper that was rejected. 
> > 
> > I'd be especially interested to hear fro=
m those of you who argued that non-quantitative papers should be rejected (=
or, at least, should have a much higher threshold to gain acceptance). Obvi=
ously I think this paper is interesting and will benefit the scientific com=
munity, partly because it suggests new ideas (though it can't quantify all =
of them yet). Do you think our field is better off barring such papers beca=
use they can't quantitatively "prove" they are better than some alternate a=
lgorithm in some way? Of course I'm not advocating that all papers should l=
ack quantitative results; just that we should not rule out such papers if t=
hey don't have statistical comparisons. I do want to stress that I always i=
nclude--and as a reviewer, insist upon--a statistical test with a p-value *=
if* a quantitative claim is made, but that policy is not inconsistent with =
the view that many interesting, subjective, qualitative observations are sc=
ientifically worthwhile too. 
> > 
> > I won't take any criticism of our pa=
per personally. I just think that sometimes arguments are more informative =
when there is a specific example to be discussed, instead of remaining enti=
rely abstract. I also think this paper is a nice example of a technique tha=
t can't be quantified in an informative way, yet remains an interesting con=
tribution. If you were our reviewer, would you insist upon a quantitative c=
omparison for this paper? How would you recommend such a test be made? Do y=
ou agree that we should encourage reviewers to reject such papers, or that =
we should work to encourage reviewers to consider such papers?
> > 
> > Her=
e is the cite and PDF: 
> > 
> > Clune J, Chen A, Lipson H (2013) Upload An=
y Object and Evolve it: Injecting Complex Geometric Patterns into CPPNs for=
 Further Evolution. Proceedings of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Comput=
ation.
> > 
> > http://jeffclune.com/publications/2013-Clune-SeededCPPN-CEC=
.pdf
> > 
> > I look forward to hearing your thoughts. 
> > 
> > Best regar=
ds,
> > Jeff Clune
> > 
> > Assistant Professor
> > Computer Science
> > Un=
iversity of Wyoming
> > jeffclune@...
> > jeffclune.com
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_711D1AE8-8CBF-4511-AE19-76C092D029B2

	charset=windows-1252

rmative way, yet remains an interesting contribution. If you were our revie=

uld you recommend such a test be made? Do you agree that we should encourag=
e reviewers to reject such papers, or that we should work to encourage revi=
ewers to consider such papers?<br>
<br>
I agree that it's hard to quantify =
the results in this paper because the result is "yup, it worked in my syste=
m." At this point, the best you could've done was (as you mentioned) compar=

he workspace, so the error for the Seeded-CPPN technique effectively is zer=

y uncertainty is how bad target based evolution would be, but that is not t=
he focus of this paper, so the experiment would be off-topic. In other word=

ips right to the correct shape=85to compare it against an obviously bad tec=

insist on quantification; it does not address a broader hypothesis, no?</di=

Here=
's what I got from the paper: You wanted to create a method to seed a 3D ob=
ject generator with a predetermined 3D object. You devised a method to enab=
le this feature based on CPPNs. You showed that it works pretty well and ma=
tches the desired object on EndlessForms.<br>
<br>
Notice how each sentence=
 narrows the relevant audience down more and more. The question went from "=
How do I seed a 3D object generator with a predetermined object?" to "How d=
o I seed a 3D object generator based on CPPNs with a predetermined object?"=
 to "How do I seed my 3D object generator based on CPPNs, EndlessForms, wit=
h a predetermined object?"<br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div=

duced on EndlessForms and show that the Seeded-CPPN technique works for any=
 object. I'd argue that we actually answered the first, broadest question a=
s well: one answer to how to seed a 3D object generator with a predetermine=
d object is to use the Seeded-CPPN technique. </div><br><blockquote ty=
pe=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: s=
tatic; z-index: auto; "><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;"=

<br>

Let's say I had my own 3D object generating website, UnlimitedForms, but it=
 was based on regular ANNs. What could I take from this paper? </p></div></=
div></div></div></blockquote><div>You would know that you could seed object=
s if you switch to CPPNs and use the Seeded-CPPN technique. That sounds che=
eky (sorry, I'm in the UK at the moment), but I think it is the honest answ=

l. </div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color:=

sg" style=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"=
><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Or what if I was only interested in 2D pictures, =
but still wanted to seed them similarly? Or what if I have no interest in e=
volving 2D/3D objects at all, but want to know clever methods for seeding a=
 GA with a predetermined phenotype? These are all important points to consi=
der when presenting a new method, especially because everyone has their own=
 pet method that they like to use.<br>
<br>
If you did the work discussed i=
n Section 4B for this paper, you would have a much easier time quantifying =
the results. You also would've gotten at a much more broadly interesting qu=
estion about evolvability while simultaneously presenting your new techniqu=
e.<br>
<br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>Agreed. Any paper =
would be stronger if it also did its Future Work section. In fact, a lot of=
 the reviewers were upset that so much time in the paper was spent discussi=
ng the future work that this technique enables. But I believe that's often =
precisely what makes new techniques interesting: the possibilities they ena=
ble. There is always a tension between doing the future work, or just menti=
oning that it can be done. For a conference paper, I think it is fine to pu=
blish a smaller package of work and point to future possible work. But I'd =
like to point out that whether there is enough work in this paper is orthog=
onal to the quantitative vs. qualitative discussion. Quite a bit of the fut=
ure evolvability work would also be qualitative. One could say "you should =
have done the quantitative portions of the future work, because then you'd =
at least have something quantitive." That's clearly the prudent strategy gi=
ven that some reviewers won't accept a paper unless it has a few quantitati=
ve comparisons, but this discussion is about whether that demand for some q=
uantitative comparison should be the prevailing attitude. There's plenty of=
 work in this area that won't be quantifiable=85.and saying that it has to =
be packaged with something quantitative shows that we have a bizarre "check=
box rule" for papers: you can publish something qualitative and interesting=
, but only if you also pair it with some quantifiable metric so you check t=
he quantitative box. If the qualitative work is inadmissible as science, as=
 the GECCO reviewer for this paper claimed, then it shouldn't be publishabl=
e even as a sub-section of a paper. And if it is admissible, then it should=
 be able to be publishable on its own (if there is enough of such qualitati=
ve work to be a publishable unit).  </div><div><br></div><blockquote t=
ype=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: =
static; z-index: auto; "><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;=

--- In <a=
 href=3D"mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, "Jeff" &l=
t;jclune@...> wrote:<br>
><br>
> Hello all,<br>
> <br>
> Our=
 recent conversation in this "Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results" thread =
was started in part because a paper I am on was rejected from GECCO for not=
 having any quantitative results. That paper was recently accepted at CEC. =
I'd be interested to hear your thoughts on this paper in light of our conve=
rsation now that you can see the specific paper that was rejected. <br>
&gt=
; <br>
> I'd be especially interested to hear from those of you who argu=
ed that non-quantitative papers should be rejected (or, at least, should ha=
ve a much higher threshold to gain acceptance). Obviously I think this pape=
r is interesting and will benefit the scientific community, partly because =
it suggests new ideas (though it can't quantify all of them yet). Do you th=
ink our field is better off barring such papers because they can't quantita=
tively "prove" they are better than some alternate algorithm in some way? O=
f course I'm not advocating that all papers should lack quantitative result=
s; just that we should not rule out such papers if they don't have statisti=
cal comparisons. I do want to stress that I always include--and as a review=
er, insist upon--a statistical test with a p-value *if* a quantitative clai=
m is made, but that policy is not inconsistent with the view that many inte=
resting, subjective, qualitative observations are scientifically worthwhile=
 too. <br>
> <br>
> I won't take any criticism of our paper personall=
y. I just think that sometimes arguments are more informative when there is=
 a specific example to be discussed, instead of remaining entirely abstract=
. I also think this paper is a nice example of a technique that can't be qu=
antified in an informative way, yet remains an interesting contribution. If=
 you were our reviewer, would you insist upon a quantitative comparison for=
 this paper? How would you recommend such a test be made? Do you agree that=
 we should encourage reviewers to reject such papers, or that we should wor=
k to encourage reviewers to consider such papers?<br>
> <br>
> Here i=
s the cite and PDF: <br>
> <br>
> Clune J, Chen A, Lipson H (2013) Up=
load Any Object and Evolve it: Injecting Complex Geometric Patterns into CP=
PNs for Further Evolution. Proceedings of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary=
 Computation.<br>
> <br>
> <a href=3D"http://jeffclune.com/publicatio=
ns/2013-Clune-SeededCPPN-CEC.pdf">http://jeffclune.com/publications/2013-Cl=
une-SeededCPPN-CEC.pdf</a><br>
> <br>
> I look forward to hearing you=
r thoughts. <br>
> <br>
